choices.text: Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix
Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane
Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding reversible cell injury, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix

 

Explanation:

 

Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix is typically associated with irreversible cell injury rather than reversible cell injury. This change indicates severe damage to the mitochondria, often due to sustained injury that compromises mitochondrial function beyond the cell's ability to recover.

 

Other Options Explained:

 

Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP): This is characteristic of reversible cell injury. It occurs due to temporary impairment of mitochondrial function, which can recover if the injurious stimulus is removed.

 

Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane: Blebbing is a response to reversible cell injury. It involves changes in the cytoskeleton and plasma membrane, which can be restored once the injury ceases.

 

Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum: This change can occur during reversible cell injury and reflects a temporary disruption in protein synthesis. If the injury is mild and transient, normal ribosomal function can resume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amorphous densities in mitochondria are a hallmark of irreversible injury, while diminished ATP production, membrane blebbing, and ribosome detachment are associated with reversible cell injury

Pyroptosis
Apoptosis
Necroptosis

questions.text: Which of the following process does not show phases of acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Apoptosis

 

Option C:

Apoptosis, or programmed cell death, is a process that generally does not trigger inflammation due to the rapid and efficient phagocytosis of apoptotic cells without releasing inflammatory intracellular contents.

 

  • Apoptosis is “caspase-dependent” programmed cell death. Cells that are dying by apoptosis secrete soluble factors that recruit phagocytes. The process of phagocytosis by apoptotic cells is so efficient that dead cells disappear, often within minutes, without leaving a trace, and inflammation is absent even in the face of extensive apoptosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Necrosis involves cell death that triggers an inflammatory response due to the release of intracellular contents into the extracellular space.

 

Option B. This is a highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death where cells swell, lose membrane integrity, and release pro-inflammatory mediators.

 

Option D. Necroptosis, sometimes referred to as programmed necrosis, is caspase-independent cell death that morphologically resembles necrosis and is associated with inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis is a caspase-dependent programmed cell death process that typically proceeds without triggering the phases of acute inflammation due to efficient clearance of dying cells.

Binding of lead to cell membrane of erythroid pre­cursors.

questions.text: The pathogenesis of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme bio­synthesis

Option A:

The pathogenesis of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning is primarily due to the inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis. Lead interferes with several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, including aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and ferrochelatase. This interference leads to a decrease in the production of heme and, subsequently, hemoglobin.

Explanation:

Option B. Lead does not bind to transferrin directly

Option C. While lead can affect cell membranes, the primary mechanism of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning is related to its impact on enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis, not direct binding to cell membranes.

Option D. Lead does not directly bind to ferritin to inhibit their breakdown. The primary effect is on heme synthesis enzymes.

Educational Objective:

The primary pathogenesis of hypochromic anemia in lead poisoning involves the inhibition of enzymes necessary for heme biosynthesis, such as aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) and ferrochelatase, leading to reduced heme and hemoglobin production.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 411, Tejinder Singh 1st/147

choices.text: Trauma
Hypoxia
Genetic abnormality involving the myocardium
Heavy metals

questions.text: A 60-year-old man suffered a massive cardiac arrest and encountered sudden death. Post mortem finding of the heart shows complete obstruction of left anterior descending artery by an atherosclerotic plaque. Myocardial injury in this patient has occurred due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoxia

 

Option B:

In this patient with complete blockage of left anterior descending artery (LAD), restricted blood supply to the myocardium would have led to reduced oxygen resulting in hypoxia.

Hypoxia is the most common cause of cell injury overall and ischemia is the most common cause of hypoxia

Oxygen is an important requirement of mitochondria for the formation of ATP; therefore, hypoxia will result in the earliest involvement of mitochondria resulting in decreased formation of ATP.

 

Other causes of cell injury include

 

  • Physical agents (extreme temperatures, electric shock, burns etc)
  • Chemical agents and drugs (Heavy metals, carbon monoxide, alcohol etc)
  • Infectious agents
  • Genetic abnormalities (Inborn errors of metabolism, chromosomal abnormalities etc)
  • Nutritional imbalances.

 

Explanation:

Option A. Trauma: Trauma by physical agents is a cause of cell injury, but does not apply in this case

Option C. Genetic abnormality involving the myocardium: Genetic abnormalities involving the myocardium such as hypertrophic and dilated cardiomyopathies can lead to hypoxia, but this case describes a classic case of cell injury die to hypoxic ischemic injury.

Option D.Heavy metals: Heavy metals can cause cell injury buy does not apply to this case.

 

Educational objective:

Hypoxia is the most common cause of cell injury overall and ischemia is the most common cause of hypoxia.

choices.text: Intracellular depletion of Ca2+
Mitochondrial dysfunction
Intact membrane
Release of lysosomal (hydrolytic) enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary consequence of diminished ATP on cellular function?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitochondrial dysfunction

 

Option B:

ATP is primarily produced in the mitochondria, and a lack of ATP indicates mitochondrial dysfunction. This can result in further energy deficits and exacerbate cell injury.

Diminished ATP leads to mitochondrial dysfunction. This exaggerates release of lysosomal enzymes and membrane damage.

 

Explanation:

Option A. Diminished ATP can actually lead to an increase in intracellular calcium as ATP-dependent mechanisms that pump calcium out of the cell fail. An increase in intracellular calcium can activate destructive enzymes and pathways.

 

Option C. Diminished ATP typically leads to damage of cellular membranes because energy-dependent ion pumps and repair mechanisms fail, rather than preserving membrane integrity.

 

Option D. A decrease in ATP can contribute to the release of lysosomal enzymes. When ATP is low, cellular components may not be maintained or recycled properly, leading to enzyme leakage and further cellular damage.

 

Educational Objective:

Diminished ATP most directly leads to mitochondrial dysfunction, as the mitochondria are the main site of ATP production within the cell. This mitochondrial dysfunction can subsequently lead to additional cellular damage, including the release of lysosomal enzymes and membrane damage.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 37

questions.text: Identify the correct combination of most and least sensitive cells to hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Most sensitive -neurons and least sensitive fibroblasts

 

Explanation:

The cells most sensitive to hypoxia are neurons and least sensitive are fibroblasts.

Among CNS cells, there is a hierarchy of sensitivity to hypoxia/ischemia: neurons are the most sensitive (Pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus/ Sommer’s sector > Cerebellar Purkinje cells > Pyramidal neurons of the cerebral cortex) although glial cells (oligodendrocytes and astrocytes) are also vulnerable

Option B. Most sensitive bone marrow cells and least sensitive neurons: represents most and least sensitive cells with respect to ionizing radiation exposure.

Amongst the body cells, the most sensitive are spermatogonia and erythroblasts, epidermal stem cells, gastrointestinal stem cells. The least sensitive are nerve cells and muscle fibers.

 

Educational objective:

 

The cells most sensitive to hypoxia are neurons and least sensitive are fibroblasts. 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed Pg: 37

choices.text: Decreased aerobic oxidative respiration
Decreased anaerobic glycolysis
Decreased production of 2,3 DPG from alternative glycolytic pathway
Decreased pentose phosphate pathway

questions.text: Identify the correct mechanism by which hypoxic cell injury occurs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased aerobic oxidative respiration

 

Option A:

 

Since hypoxia is a deficiency of oxygen, it causes cell injury by affecting aerobic oxidative respiration. Hypoxia will result in the earliest involvement of mitochondria resulting in decreased formation of ATP. Diminished ATP constitutes the critical mechanism of the cellular injury which leads to:

 

  1. Intracellular accumulation of Ca+2
  2. Mitochondrial dysfunction
  3. Membrane damage
  4. Release of lysosomal (hydrolytic) enzymes

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Decreased anaerobic glycolysis: Anaerobic glycolysis actually increases in response to hypoxia as the cell attempts to compensate for the lack of oxygen and maintain ATP production.

 

Option C. Decreased production of 2,3 DPG from alternative glycolytic pathway: This is not the primary mechanism of hypoxic cell injury. While changes in 2,3-DPG levels affect oxygen release from hemoglobin, they do not directly cause cellular injury.

 

Option D. Decreased pentose phosphate pathway: This pathway operates independently of oxygen and ATP, so hypoxia does not have a significant direct impact on its activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary mechanism of hypoxic cell injury is decreased aerobic oxidative respiration which directly results in diminished ATP production and consequent cellular dysfunction.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 37 Dacie and Lewis 11th edition- pg:266

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding reversible cellular injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cellular fragmentation in light microscopy is diagnostic

 

Option D:

 

  • Cellular fragmentation is a feature of irreversible cell injury

  • Cellular fragmentation usually indicates irreversible cell injury and cell death, not reversible injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Cellular swelling, or hydropic change, is one of the earliest manifestations of cellular injury and indicates a reversible stage where function may be restored upon removal of the insult.

 

Option B. Fatty change, or steatosis, in cells, such as hepatocytes, is typically reversible when the underlying cause (such as alcohol abuse) is removed.

 

Option C. Blebbing of the plasma membrane is a reversible change often seen in injured cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cellular fragmentation seen in light microscopy is indicative of irreversible cell injury, such as necrosis, and is not a feature of reversible cell injury.

choices.text: It occurs due to the accumulation of triglycerides
Seen exclusively in reversible injury
Seen exclusively in irreversible cell injury
Thought to be derived from damaged cellular membranes

questions.text: Electron microscopy was performed in a renal biopsy obtained from a 45-year-old female on aminoglycoside therapy. Image shows a peculiar finding (marked with an  arrow). Which is true regarding this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thought to be derived from damaged cellular membranes

 

Option D:

 

  • The finding shown in image having a whorled appearance is â€œMyelin figuresâ€.

  • Myelin figures are indeed derived from phospholipids, and they typically represent areas of cellular membrane damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myelin figures are composed of phospholipids, not triglycerides.

 

Option B and Option C. Myelin figures can be observed in both reversible and irreversible cell injury scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myelin figures, which may be seen in renal biopsies from patients with drug-induced nephrotoxicity, are derived from damaged cellular membranes and can be indicative of both reversible and irreversible cell injury.

 

 

Why myelin figures are seen in both reversible and irreversible cell injury? 

 

Reversible injury (early stage):

 

  • In mild/moderate injury, damage to membranes starts.
  • The injured membranes can form small amounts of myelin figures.
  • At this point, the cell may still recover if the stress is removed.
  • Typical associated changes: cell swelling (hydropic change), dilation of ER, ribosome detachment.

 

So, few or small myelin figures can be seen during reversible injury as the cell responds to stress.

 

Irreversible injury (severe stage):

 

  • When damage becomes severe and progressive â†’ massive membrane breakdown.
  • The number and size of myelin figures increase markedly.
  • They can become large, prominent, and sometimes are phagocytosed by macrophages or degraded into fatty acids â†’ leading to calcium deposits (calcification).

 

So, in irreversible injury, abundant myelin figures reflect extensive, fatal membrane damage.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 39 Image attribute: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0006295202011103

Dense deposition of mitochondria
Bleb formation

questions.text: All are features of reversible cell injury except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense deposition of mitochondria

 

Option B:

 

Dense mitochondrial deposition suggests irreversible injury, where mitochondria undergo high-amplitude swelling and structural damage, which is often a point of no return.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is a feature of reversible cell injury, where swelling of organelles such as the endoplasmic reticulum occurs as a response to cell injury before permanent damage sets in.

 

Option C. Blebbing of the plasma membrane is a sign of reversible cell injury where the cell morphology is altered but can be restored if the injurious stimulus is removed.

 

Option D. A decrease in ribosomal function (detachment of ribosomes from the rough endoplasmic reticulum) is seen with reversible cell injury as a part of the cellular stress response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dense deposition of mitochondria is not a feature of reversible cell injury but rather indicates irreversible damage, typically associated with severe structural changes within the mitochondria.

 

Reversible cell injury (sublethal injury):

 

  • Cell is injured but can recover if stimulus is removed.
  • Causes: mild ischemia, mild toxins, etc.

questions.text:
Please read the statements carefully as this is an assertion and reason question

 

Assertion (A): Necrotic cells have a glassy, homogenous appearance when compared to normal cells in irreversible cell injury.

 

Reason (R): There may be loss of nuclear material in irreversible cell injury
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are the true but Reason (R) is not the correct explanation of Assertion (A)

 

Option B:

 

Assertion (A):

 

Necrotic cells have a glassy, homogeneous appearance when compared to normal cells in irreversible cell injury.

 

  • True
  • In irreversible injury â†’ necrosis:
    • Cytoplasm appears more eosinophilic (pink)
    • Glassy, homogeneous look
  • This happens because:
    • Loss of glycogen particles
    • Protein denaturation
    • Loss of cell detail â†’ makes cytoplasm look smooth and glassy

 

Reason (R):

 

There may be loss of nuclear material in irreversible cell injury

 

  • True
  • In necrosis, nuclei undergo:
    • Pyknosis (shrinkage, dark)
    • Karyorrhexis (fragmentation)
    • Karyolysis (fading, loss)
  • So yes, there is loss of nuclear material.
  • The glassy, homogeneous cytoplasmic appearance is mainly due to:
    • Loss of glycogen
    • Denaturation and aggregation of cytoplasmic proteins
  • The loss of nuclear material does happen in necrosis, but it does not explain the glassy appearance of the cytoplasm.
  • Nuclear changes and cytoplasmic changes are parallel but separate processes.

 

The necrotic cell may have a glassy homogeneous appearance relative to normal cells, mainly as a result of the loss of glycogen particles. When enzymes have digested the cellâ€™s organelles, the cytoplasm becomes vacuolated and appears moth-eaten.

 

However, loss of nuclear material is also a characteristic finding in irreversible cellular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotic cells can exhibit a glassy, homogeneous appearance due to the loss of intracellular components like glycogen, while the loss of nuclear material is also a characteristic of irreversible cell injury, but it is not the explanation for the glassy appearance.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 40

questions.text:
Please read the statements carefully as this is an assertion and reason question: 

 

Assertion (A): One of the hallmarks of irreversible cell injury is damaged cell membrane

 

Reason (R): When intracellular calcium is increased, activation of phospholipase enzyme is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are the true and Reason (R) is a correct    explanation of Assertion (A).

 

Option A:

 

Assertion (A):

 

One of the hallmarks of irreversible cell injury is damaged cell membrane

 

  • True
  • Loss of membrane integrity (plasma membrane & mitochondrial membrane) is indeed a key hallmark of irreversible injury.
  • Once membrane damage is severe â†’ cell contents leak out â†’ cell death.

 

Reason (R):

 

When intracellular calcium is increased, activation of phospholipase enzyme is seen

 

  • True
  • In cell injury, increased cytosolic CaÂ²âº activates:
    • Phospholipases â†’ degrade membrane phospholipids
    • Proteases â†’ damage cytoskeleton
    • Endonucleases â†’ damage DNA
    • ATPases â†’ deplete ATP further
  • This contributes to membrane damage.

 

Does the Reason correctly explain the Assertion?

 

  • Yes
  • Increased intracellular calcium â†’ activation of phospholipases â†’ directly causes membrane phospholipid degradation â†’ membrane damage.
  • So, the reason directly explains why membrane damage (the hallmark) happens.

 

When intracellular calcium is increased, activation of phospholipase enzyme is seen. This contributes to damaged cell membrane which is a feature of irreversible injury. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damaged cell membranes are a hallmark of irreversible cell injury, and this is due in part to the increased intracellular calcium levels that lead to phospholipase activation, which degrades membrane lipids.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 39
